item.title: The impedance mismatch is our fault
item.description:
InfoQ Link

Speaker

Stuart Halloway, co-creator of Datomic

Thoughts

Datomic is a very very interesting peace of technology, I should find more time to work with this. I might look for a new side project to experiment with new ideas.

Stuart has shaped a lot of how I think about programming today, thanks again.

Quotes

“All information in the database is to be represented in only one way, namely by valyes in column positions within row of tables” - by Codd

“… Essentially the ORM can handle about 80-90% of the mapping problems..” - by Martin Fowler

“I don’t slow down when you watch me”

Recommendations

  1. Read “The Vietnam of computer science”
  2. Don’t give up! If you simplify OO and RDMS, you will find the building blocks for a general-purpose approach to data
  3. Read “The Vietnam of computer science a response”
  4. This is not related to performace, many round-trips, this is related to data being changed while you are in the between of the round trips
  5. Transactions are awesome

item.title: Clojure Java Interop
item.description:
Youtube Link

Speaker

Stuart Halloway, Founder of Cognitect

Thoughts

I had to use some pure-Java libraries to deal with XSLX data format lazily and that was a very simple learning curve for a person that has never programmed in Java before (me!). For some reason, I had never thought about using Clojure from Java.

Code Nice Examples

Java - Chaining

person.getAddress().getZipCode()

Clojure - Chaining

(.. person getAddress getZipCode)

item.title: Running with Scissors
item.description:
Youtube Link

Speaker

Stuart Halloway, Founder of Cognitect

Thoughts

I still have difficult to understand what the sentence “your running program is tangible." I never connected to a REPL created by running a jar file, but I often have some code running in remote servers using lein ring server or something similar which I can navigate around the namespaces and manipulate the code. I also started to leave test setup inside a comment block. VERY USEFUL!

item.title: Debugging with the Scientific Method
item.description:
Youtube Link

Speaker

Stuart Halloway, Founder of Cognitect

Thoughts

I am running closely the support team at my company today and the number of findings you get about software and people interactions is incredible. I first didn’t like the position at all, but I was not really understanding what was happening. The evolution of a system with your business is very complex and interesting with tons of knowledge to take on for future products.

Quotes

“If you don’t know where you are going, you might wind up someplace else”

“Weak science is stronger than strong tools”

A thousand dollar slide

Problem statements; steps you took, what you expected, what actually happened

Book

  1. Why Programs Fail - A guide to systematic debugging
  2. The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
  3. The Bell Curve
